**In Favor of Students Being Involved in Curriculum Design:**

Potential Benefit #1: Enhanced Student Engagement

* Involving students in curriculum design leads to higher engagement rates from both teachers and students.
By granting some measure of input power it creates increased incentive towards following and completing educational courses of interest with improved knowledge outcomes.

Benefits of Student Engagement Include:
   Better comprehension and retention of material,
      Higher motivation for active participation in lessons.
The students better relate with materials created collaboratively,  due its direct connection with the world around us hence it results in elevated participation level (Bolstad & Kachur,2022).
This comes from providing relevant knowledge for each individual student as well incorporating their diverse opinions.
Student contribution enables the design towards curriculum aligned with contemporary concerns along with real-world issues.

When educators involve students in course development learners develop a sense of ownership for material covered throughout class duration contributing higher degrees of attention,] to better absorb knowledge which fosters growth (Ebert et al.,2020).
Forcing teachers to consider what makes courses relevant could encourage students attend and do the readings.

When students help choose what they learn, (within certain frameworks), they naturally take on greater responsibility for retaining what was taught and ultimately exhibit more passionate interest to grasp ideas - translating into better overall academic outcomes.
When offered input,], learners will indeed develop that sense perception that their ideas count.

Benefit of Potential Student Motivation Boost:

By taking ownership over what is learned it can boost motivation levels when compared with strictly adhering to material set-out by others without input from the end user: the students themselves.

2) Inherent Diversity Provides Wider Insights:
   * By having multiple stakeholders partake in setting an instructional path there would naturally appear a greater diversity providing varied perspectives.

Benefit To Better Aligned Learning Paths:

A student perspective integrated directly provides unique perspectives for designing personalized study plans.
Improved learning, at-home and classroom activities often lead to retention rate increases.
When incorporating individual preferences within a group setting this has been observed among schools using co-curricular activities effectively (Kohn 1993).

Potential Benefi t#2: Valuable Perspectives Contributed:

With more time devoted to understanding the curriculum itself, (theyre at least living this process firsthand), often their perspectives could lead towards discovering newer ideas unexplored so far and enhance current materials being covered.

• A voice can ensure better adaptation:
Student's active participation guarantees consideration of unique viewpoints as each participant brings varied insights & perspectives into the classroom leading to an enriched learning atmosphere & ultimately more adapted teaching strategies adapting the learning objectives towards an evolving population.

**Arguments Against Student Participation in Curriculum Design:**

Drawback Potential Limitations Based upon Age and Learning Stage


It may be argued that young pupils often fail to recognize what they'll find useful later & so will most likely prioritize topics which appeal only currently - creating unrealistic scenarios.

**Against the Idea of Students Taking Part in Curriculum Design:**

Possible Detriment: Quality Control Compromised:

Without proper training as well as lack of familiarity about curriculum building can lead in poorly designed classes hindering understanding outcomes due lacking alignment & sequencing across courses within certain time-span as a direct consequence not incorporating sound pedagical guidelines as they emerge while leaving out foundational knowledge transfer.

Potential Benefit #3: Fostering Innovation through Collaboration

Incorporation of diverse opinions promotes innovation within curriculum creation and contributes actively in improving academic courses tailored according towards real students.

The Increased Perspective in Education Reform through Student-led Change:

Students possess unique insight into how educators might enhance current curriculum.

**Argument Against Involvement of Students in Curriculum Design :*

Drawback #1: Lack of Educational Expertise :

* Concerns over limitations on knowledge pertaining directly or indirectly affecting content within fields not mastered yet, we may be putting the onus partially on kids still learning - this affects overall integrity in syllabus content possibly undermining its credibility for all affected student stakeholders.

For Better Cultural Adaptability:
Incorporating inputs from students aids in making curriculums reflect and be relevant within modern diversity including diverse upbringings, values cultural customs thus avoiding cultural appropriation issues through incorporating diverse experiences to contribute and promote cultural inclusion effectively & enrich our educational systems further.

Additional Key Arguments include (though not mentioned specifically elsewhere in this passage though) 
A wider skillset development:
Collaborative problem-solving skills which will assist their professional lives; a chance for teachers 
Teachers and school management understand needs more fully:

Student suggestions reflect concerns within class demographics hence assisting teachers tailor approaches more aptly aligned with learner abilities.

**Challenges Against Student-Curriculum Input**

Shortcoming 1: Limitation in Expertise:

- Although highly motivated pupils certainly do their part actively considering factors, their lack of academic background prevents a comprehensive perspective - hence possibly not understanding specific learning goals or pedagogical considerations.

**Opposite Standpoint of Non-Inclusion in Curriculum Design Decision:**

Drawback #1: Students Lack Expertise

**Against Involving Students in Curriculum Design:**

Drawback #1 : Lack of Expertise and Inconsistent Vision

Consequences due of Conflicting Vision for Educational Reform:

Each contributing student voice may hold opposing thoughts thereby obstructing constructive collaboration thus leading multiple and unclear perspectives and subsequently reducing efficiency towards change.

**Against Involving Students in Curriculum Design:**

Drawback# 1 Limitation due to restricted understanding & resources

As student has yet limited knowledge regarding teaching approaches educational psychology alongwith available educational technologies they cannot efficiently design a comprehensive and practical for various students' age span which demands continuous up-dates throughout their years.
